choices.answer_tooltip: Regularly verify that your backup data is what you expect by running a script to validate data integrity, schema, and queries. choices.heading: Validating backups

choices.title: We conduct outage retrospectives
choices.answer_tooltip: No amount of safeguards or preparation can prevent every possible incident, and sometimes simple human error can have significant consequences to a development project. You can't avoid it, but you can learn from it and take steps to minimize the chances of a similar incident in the future. The question is how software organizations can best go about learning from mistakes with agile postmortems.
choices.heading: Outage retrospectives

choices.title: Regional failure plans are documented
choices.answer_tooltip: When you run production workloads on cloud, you might use a globally distributed system so that if something goes wrong in one region, the application continues to provide service even if it's less widely available. In essence, that application invokes its DR plan.
choices.heading: Planning for regional failures

choices.title: Backups are stored securely
choices.answer_tooltip: Backups are about protecting data, applications, and systems that are important to the organization. In operations environments, it’s easy to provide backups: pick the workload that needs hyper-availability and back it up. choices.output: Data Sovereignty is the idea that data are subject to the laws and governance structures within the nation it is collected. Learn More: [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/azure-physical-security](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/azure-physical-security)

choices.title: Ensure that no single user account has access to both production and backup data.
choices.answer_tooltip: Your data backups are compromised if one single user account has permission to write to both production and backup sources. choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to have a cohesive view of issues. Inability to have an up-to- date picture of system health.
choices.output: Use Azure Log Analytics for viewing data for a particular application. Utilize Service Map and Application Map for logs across multiple components.

choices.title: Are there automated alerts and notifications?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to detect patterns or conditions that indicate potential or current issues and send alerts to address them.
choices.output: Create, view, and manage alerts using Azure Monitor. Use Log Analytics Alerts based on conditions in Log Analytics data.

choices.title: How do you monitor assets and resources for expiration?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to determine services or features that depend on the expiration of resources.
choices.output: Use Azure VM expire and certificate monitoring.

questions.title: Management

choices.title: Are there manual activities to automate?
choices.answer_tooltip: Possibility of error-prone manual handling of repetitive operations.
choices.output: Use Azure Automation for complete control during deployment, operations, and decommissioning of workloads and resources.

choices.title: Do you have existing scripts for deployment?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to minimize the amount of manual configuration needed to provision resources.
choices.output: Utilize Azure Resource Manager templates and scripts for automated resource provisioning.

choices.title: Are you planning to use containers?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to create self- contained packages, including all dependencies and files needed to run the application, which simplifies the deployment.
choices.output: Use VSTS hosted CI/CD for containers to create and deploy containers.

choices.title: Do you have an operations manual?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to refer to any documented operations scenarios and mitigation plans during a failure or other disruption in service.
choices.output: Use Azure Operations Management Suite (OMS) for process automation.

choices.title: Do you have on-call procedures documented?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to refer to on-call duties, schedules, and procedures.
choices.output: Employ third-party extensions such as Remedy OnDemand to notify on-call responders for critical VSTS work items.

choices.title: Do you have escalation procedures documented?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to deal with outages, including identifying support contacts and escalation paths.
choices.output: Practice agile planning and portfolio management with VSTS for a full view of the work escalation and decomposition of tasks.

choices.title: How do you implement configuration management?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to plan, create, and record configuration changes and make them visible to operations.
choices.output: Employ VSTS configuration management for visibility to dev and operations teams. Use PowerShell DSC for configuration management.

choices.title: Do you have an Azure support plan?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to understand details of the plan, how the support process works, getting service limits changed, and opening support tickets.
choices.output: Understand Azure support plans. Refer to Azure Support FAQs.

choices.title: Have you implemented RBAC?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to manage access to resources and enforce security principles.
choices.output: Use role-based access control (RBAC) to grant access based on Azure Active Directory identities and groups.

choices.title: Do you use a bug-tracking system?
choices.answer_tooltip: Possibility of missed items, duplicate work, or introduction of additional problems.
choices.output: Utilize VSTS bug tracking tool for establishing links between code and bugs. Use Bugzilla integration with VSTS.

choices.title: Do you audit and track changes in code and infrastructure?
choices.answer_tooltip: Inability to track and audit changes (code, infrastructure, configuration, documentation, and scripts).
choices.output: Employ VSTS history and auditing for a consolidated view of changes to code and infrastructure.
